{{Use dmy dates|date=November 2012}} {{Update|the 31 Oct 2014 settlement|date=October 2014}} [[File:Major Russian Gas Pipelines to Europe.svg|thumb|350px|Natural gas pipelines from Russia to Europe]] The '''Russia–Ukraine gas disputes''' refer to a number of disputes between Ukrainian oil and gas company [[Naftogaz|Naftohaz Ukrayiny]] and Russian gas supplier [[Gazprom]] over [[natural gas]] supplies, prices, and debts. These disputes have grown beyond simple business disputes into transnational political issues—involving political leaders from several countries—that threaten natural gas supplies in numerous European countries dependent on natural gas imports from Russian suppliers, which are transported through [[Ukraine]]. Russia provides approximately a quarter of the natural gas consumed in the European Union; approximately 80% of those exports travel through pipelines across Ukrainian soil prior to arriving in the EU.<ref name=BBC182009/>
A serious dispute began in March 2005 over the price of natural gas supplied and the cost of transit. During this conflict, Russia claimed Ukraine was not paying for gas, but diverting that which was intended to be exported to the EU from the pipelines. Ukrainian officials at first denied the accusation,<ref name=bbc010106> {{Cite news| title = Ukraine gas row hits EU supplies| publisher=BBC| date =1 January 2006| url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4573572.stm|accessdate =16 December 2008}}</ref><ref name=bbc020106/> but later Naftogaz admitted that natural gas intended for other European countries was retained and used for domestic needs. The dispute reached a high point on 1 January 2006, when Russia cut off all gas supplies passing through Ukrainian territory.<ref name=bbc240106> {{Cite news| title = Ukraine takes extra Russian gas| publisher=BBC| date =24 January 2006| url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/4642684.stm|accessdate =16 December 2008}}</ref> On 4 January 2006, a preliminary agreement between Russia and Ukraine was achieved, and the supply was restored. The situation calmed until October 2007 when new disputes began over Ukrainian gas debts. This led to reduction of gas supplies in March 2008. During the last months of 2008, relations once again became tense when Ukraine and Russia could not agree on the debts owed by Ukraine.<ref name="November">{{Cite news|title=Ukraine - time to pay gas bills |publisher=Russia Today |date=26 November 2008 |url=http://www.russiatoday.com/news/news/33776 |accessdate=17 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090123134151/http://www.russiatoday.com/news/news/33776 |archivedate=23 January 2009 }}</ref>
In January 2009, this disagreement resulted in supply disruptions in many European nations, with eighteen European countries reporting major drops in or complete cut-offs of their gas supplies transported through Ukraine from Russia.<ref name=reutersfactbox712009/><ref>{{cite news |first=Leo|last=Cendrowicz |date=9 January 2009 |url=http://www.time.com/time/world/article/0,8599,1870597,00.html |title=Russia-Europe Gas Spat Ends—For Now |work=Time |accessdate=9 January 2009}}</ref> In September 2009 officials from both countries stated they felt the situation was under control and that there would be no more conflicts over the topic,<ref name="Reuters792009"/><ref> {{Cite news| title = There are no controversies on gas issues between Ukraine and Russia| publisher=[[UNIAN]]| date =8 September 2009| url=http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-335038.html| accessdate =8 September 2009}}</ref> at least until the [[Ukrainian 2010 presidential elections]].<ref>{{Cite news| title = Gazprom sees political risk to Ukraine gas payments| publisher=[[Reuters]]| date =12 September 2009|url= https://www.reuters.com/article/rbssOilGasExplorationProduction/idUSLC31093620090912?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0| accessdate =12 September 2009| first=Janet| last=McBride}}</ref> However, in October 2009, another disagreement arose about the amount of gas Ukraine would import from Russia in 2010. Ukraine intended to import less gas in 2010 as a result of reduced industry needs because of its [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis|economic recession]]; however, Gazprom insisted that Ukraine fulfill its contractual obligations and purchase the previously agreed upon quantities of gas.<ref name="Kyiv Post8102009">{{Cite news| title = Ukraine, Russia's Gazprom disagree on 2010 imports| publisher=[[Kyiv Post]]| date =8 October 2009| url= http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/50341| accessdate =8 October 2009}}</ref>
On 8 June 2010, a Stockholm court of arbitration ruled [[Naftohaz]] of Ukraine must return {{convert|12.1|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas to [[RosUkrEnergo]], a [[Switzerland|Swiss-based]] company in which Gazprom controls a 50% stake. Russia accused Ukrainian side of diverting gas from pipelines passing through Ukraine in 2009.<ref>{{cite web|url=http://mignews.com.ua/en/articles/28412.html|title=Ukraine to remain without gas because of RosUkrEnergo?|work=Mignews.com.ua|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref><ref>{{cite web|url=http://minprom.ua/news/45115.html|title=Бойко обещает как-то удовлетворить Фирташа|publisher=|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref> Several high-ranking Ukrainian officials stated the return "would not be quick".<ref>{{cite web|url=http://www.pravda.com.ua/rus/news/2010/06/11/5132262/|title=Бойко объяснил Фирташу, что газ он быстро не получит|work=Украинская правда|accessdate=2 May 2016}}</ref>
Russia plans to completely abandon gas supplies to Europe through Ukraine after 2018.<ref>[http://tass.ru/en/infographics/7275 Gas Pipelines to Europe by 2018]. ''[[Russian News Agency "TASS"]]''.</ref><ref>[http://tass.ru/en/economy/773794 Gas supplies to bypass Ukraine from 2019 — Gazprom]. ''[[Russian News Agency "TASS"]]''. 2014-01-28.</ref> Gazprom has already substantially reduced the volumes of gas it transits across Ukraine, and expressed its intention of reducing the level further by means of transit diversification pipelines (Nord Stream, Turkish Stream, etc).<ref>{{Cite news|url=https://www.oxfordenergy.org/publications/russian-gas-transit-across-ukraine-post-2019-pipeline-scenarios-gas-flow-consequences-and-regulatory-constraints/|title=Russian Gas Transit Across Ukraine Post-2019 – pipeline scenarios, gas flow consequences, and regulatory constraints|last=Pirani|first=Simon|date=February 2016|work=|publisher=Oxford Institute for Energy Studies|last2=Yafimava|first2=Katja|publication-place=Oxford, United Kingdom|isbn=9781784670542|oclc=|access-date=18 January 2017|via=}}</ref>
==Historical background== {{Refimprove section|date=July 2010}} After the [[dissolution of the Soviet Union]], oil import prices to Ukraine reached world market levels in 1993. However, gas import prices and transit fees remained below European levels for Russian exports to Europe through pipelines in Ukraine; these were set in bilateral negotiations.<ref name=pirani>{{Cite book| title = Ukraine's Gas Sector| last = Pirani| first = Simon| publisher = [[Oxford Institute for Energy Studies]]| year = 2007| url = http://www.oxfordenergy.org/pdfs/NG21.pdf| format = PDF| accessdate = 21 December 2008| isbn = 978-1-901795-63-9| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20080527194203/http://www.oxfordenergy.org/pdfs/NG21.pdf| archivedate = 27 May 2008| df = dmy-all}}</ref> At the same time Ukraine remained the main transit corridor for Russia's gas export. In 2004–2005, 80% of Russian gas exports to the European Union were made through Ukrainian territory.<ref name=iea>{{Cite book| title = Ukraine: Energy Policy Review 2006| publisher=[[International Energy Agency|IEA]]/[[Organisation for Economic Co-operation and Development|OECD]]| year = 2006| url= http://www.iea.org/textbase/nppdf/free/2006/ukraine2006.pdf| pages = 204; 220| format = PDF| accessdate =21 December 2008| isbn =92-64-10991-9}}</ref><ref name=nichol>{{Cite journal| title = Russia’s Cutoff of Natural Gas to Ukraine: Context and Implications| last = Nichol| first = Jim| author2 = Woehrel, Steven| author3 = Gelb, Bernhard A.| publisher = CRS Report| date = 15 February 2006| url = http://www.italy.usembassy.gov/pdf/other/RS22378.pdf| format = PDF| accessdate = 21 December 2008| id = RS22378| deadurl = yes| archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090114195333/http://www.italy.usembassy.gov/pdf/other/RS22378.pdf| archivedate = 14 January 2009| df = dmy-all}}</ref> Two-thirds of Gazprom's revenue comes from the sale of gas that crosses Ukraine.<ref name=wq> {{Cite journal |title=Where East Meets West: European Gas and Ukrainian Reality |last=Chow |first=Edward |author2=Elkind, Jonathan |journal=[[The Washington Quarterly]] |publisher=[[Center for Strategic and International Studies]] |issue=1 |volume=32 |year=2009 |url=http://www.twq.com/09winter/docs/09jan_ChowElkind.pdf |format=PDF |accessdate=10 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090114195332/http://www.twq.com/09winter/docs/09jan_ChowElkind.pdf |archivedate=14 January 2009 |df=dmy }} </ref>
Ukraine's own annual gas consumption in 2004–2005 was around {{convert|80|e9m3|abbr=off}}, of which around {{convert|20|e9m3|abbr=off}} were produced domestically, {{convert|36|e9m3|abbr=off}} were bought from [[Turkmenistan]], and {{convert|17|e9m3|abbr=off}} were received from Russia in exchange for transport of Russian natural gas. The remaining {{convert|8|e9m3|abbr=off}} were purchased from Russia.<ref name=rian20120> {{Cite news| title = Russia-Ukraine gas dispute remains unsettled | publisher=RIA Novosti | date =20 December 2005| url= http://en.rian.ru/russia/20051220/42586383.html | accessdate =21 December 2008}} </ref> The gas trading system differed substantially from the gas sale to the European Union and caused problems in the form of large-scale deliveries of relatively cheap Russian gas causing an increase of energy-intensive industries and supporting Ukraine's status as one of the world's least [[Efficient energy use|energy-efficient]] countries and largest gas importers, the accumulation of Ukrainian debts and non-payment of same, unsanctioned diversion of gas and alleged theft from the transit system, and Russian pressure on Ukraine to hand over infrastructure in return for relief of debts accumulated over natural gas transactions.<ref name=pirani/>
Gas trading was conducted under a framework of bilateral intergovernmental agreements which provided for sales, transit volumes, gas prices, gas storage, and other issues such as the establishment of production joint ventures.<ref name=":0">{{Cite web|url=https://www.oxfordenergy.org/wpcms/wp-content/uploads/2010/11/NG21-UkrainesGasSector-SimonPirani-2007.pdf|title=UKRAINE’S GAS SECTOR|last=Pirani|first=Simon|date=June 2007|website=Oxford Institute for Energy Studies|access-date=}}</ref> Commercial agreements were negotiated between the relevant companies within the guidelines and dictates of that framework and supplemented by annual agreements specifying exact prices and volumes for the following year.<ref name=":0" /> Gas sales prices and transit tariffs were determined in relationship to each other.<ref name=pirani/> Commercial agreements and trade relations have been non-transparent and trade has been conducted via intermediaries such as [[Itera]], [[EuralTransGaz]], and [[RosUkrEnergo]]. RosUkrEnergo's involvement in the Russian-Ukrainian gas trade has been controversial. There are allegations that the company is controlled by [[Semion Mogilevich]] and its beneficiaries include strategically placed officials in the Russian and Ukrainian gas industries and governmental structures related to the energy sector.<ref name=wq/><ref name=bbc061106>According to former Ukrainian Prime Minister Yulia Timochenko, RosUkrEnergo is controlled by [[Semion Mogilevich]]. {{Cite news | title = The High Price of Gas: Transcript | publisher=BBC | date =6 November 2006 | url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/panorama/6121508.stm | accessdate =21 January 2009}} </ref> Russian Prime Minister [[Vladimir Putin]] has made accusations that RosUkrEnergo is owned by a business ally of Ukraine's ex-president, [[Viktor Yushchenko]].<ref name=nyt080109> {{Cite news | title = Deal Struck to End Gas Cutoff | author=David Jolly |work=New York Times | date =8 January 2009 | url=https://www.nytimes.com/2009/01/09/world/europe/09gazprom.html?_r=1&partner=rss&emc=rss | accessdate =21 January 2009}} </ref> The Ukrainian investigation into RosUkrEnergo, during [[Yulia Tymoshenko]]'s first term as Prime Minister, was closed after she was fired by Yushchenko in September 2005.<ref name=mt280108> {{Cite news | title = Mogilevich Arrested With Arbat Boss |author1=Nikolaus von Twickel |author2=Max Delany |author3=Natalya Krainova |work=New York Times | date =28 January 2008 | url=http://www.moscowtimes.ru/article/1010/42/303006.htm | accessdate =21 January 2009}} </ref>
According to a contract between Gazprom and Naftogaz signed on 21 June 2002, payment for the transfer of Russian natural gas through the [[Natural gas transmission system of Ukraine|Ukrainian pipeline system]] had been made in exchange for no more than 15% of the gas pumped through Ukrainian territory to be taken in lieu of cash.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Politics and Complexities of Crisis Management in Ukraine: A Historical Perspective|last=Gregory Simons, Mykola Kapitonenko, Viktor Lavrenyuk, Erik Vlaeminck|first=|publisher=Routledge|year=2017|isbn=9781317020523|location=|pages=}}</ref><ref>{{Cite web|url=https://siteresources.worldbank.org/INTECAREGTOPENERGY/34004325-1112025344408/20772948/ukrainegassector.pdf|title=Ukraine: Challenges Facing the Gas Sector|last=World Bank|first=|date=September 2003|website=THE WORLD BANK - International Bank for Reconstruction and Development|access-date=}}</ref> This contract was supposed to be valid until the end of 2013.<ref>{{Cite book|title=The Baker & McKenzie International Arbitration Yearbook 2009|last=|first=|publisher=Wolters Kluwer Russia|year=2010|isbn=9785466005950|location=|pages=361}}</ref> On 9 August 2004, the two companies signed an addendum to the contract, according to which the amount of gas given as a payment was calculated based on a tariff of US$1.09 for the transportation of 1,000 cubic meters of natural gas over a distance of {{convert|100|km|mi}}; the addendum further stated the price of the natural gas supplied to Ukraine was to be $50 per 1,000 cubic meters (approximately $1.40 per million [[British thermal unit|Btu]]).<ref name=pravda221205/> This price was constant notwithstanding the gas prices in the European markets.<ref name=regneum100106> {{Cite news| title=Expert: Ukraine vs Gazprom: the price of the problem| publisher=Regnum| date=10 January 2006| url=http://www.regnum.ru/english/569483.html| accessdate=15 December 2008| deadurl=yes| archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090402145716/http://www.regnum.ru/english/569483.html| archivedate=2 April 2009| df=dmy-all}} </ref> According to the addendum the price was not subject to change until the end of 2009.<ref name=pravda221205> {{Cite news| title = Україна перехоплює ініціативу в газовій війні. Читайте документи | publisher=Українська правда | date =22 December 2005 | url= http://pravda.com.ua/news/2005/12/22/36935.htm | accessdate =15 December 2008}} </ref> Gazprom argued that this addendum was only applicable provided that the two countries sign an annual intergovernmental protocol that has higher legal status for specifying the terms of gas transit.<ref name=korrespondent231205> {{Cite news | script-title=ru:"Газпром": Цена газа для Украины может составить $500-700 | publisher=Korrespondent | date =23 December 2005 | url= http://korrespondent.net/business/140219 | accessdate =15 December 2008 | language = Russian}} </ref> According to Gazprom, the addendum becomes void as the annual protocol had not been signed for 2006 under the required terms.<ref name=gazprom071205>{{Cite news|title=Comment on Naftagaz Ukrainy's statement from 7 December 2005 |publisher=[[Gazprom]] |date=7 December 2005 |url=http://www.gazprom.com/eng/news/2005/12/18443.shtml |accessdate=15 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081012115241/http://www.gazprom.com/eng/news/2005/12/18443.shtml |archivedate=12 October 2008 }} </ref> Russia claimed that Gazprom's subsidies to the Ukrainian economy amounted to billions of dollars.<ref name=ua301205> {{Cite news | title = Обнародован текст стенограммы "газовых переговоров" | publisher=From-UA | date =30 December 2005 | url= http://www.from-ua.com/news/43b5160a4b11f | accessdate =15 December 2008}} </ref>
According to the agreement of 2006, RosUkrEnergo was to receive no more than 20 percent of the total delivered gas, which in 2007 was {{convert|15|e9m3|abbr=off}} of {{convert|73|e9m3|abbr=off}}.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}}
==Disputes of the 1990s== Initial disputes concerning gas debts and non-payment appeared immediately after the collapse of the Soviet Union.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} As a result of disputes over non-payments by Ukraine, Russia suspended natural gas exports several times between 1992 and 1994. This led to the illicit diversion of Russian natural gas exports from transit pipelines by Ukrainian companies and institutions in September 1993 and November 1994.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} The diversion of gas was acknowledged by Ukraine, while accusations of other diversions were disputed.<ref name="pirani"/> In September 1993, at a summit conference in [[Massandra]], [[Crimea]], Russian President Boris Yeltsin offered to [[President of Ukraine|Ukrainian President]] [[Leonid Kravchuk]] to forgive Ukrainian debts in return for control of the [[Black Sea Fleet]] and Ukraine's nuclear arsenal.<ref name=D>{{Cite book |title = Economic Interdependence in Ukrainian-Russian Relations |publisher = State University of New York SUNY Press |year = 1999 |page = 78 |url = http://www.clas.ufl.edu/dean/danieri.html |format = paperback |accessdate = 25 March 2014 |isbn = 0-79-14-4245-4 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20140325234952/http://www.clas.ufl.edu/dean/danieri.html |archivedate = 25 March 2014 |df = dmy-all }}</ref>{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} After a strong negative reaction from politicians in [[Kiev]], the idea was abandoned.<ref name=pirani/> An intergovernmental agreement was drafted on gas issues, including a clause stating Ukraine would permit Gazprom to participate in the privatization of Ukrainian enterprises in gas and other sectors.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} In March 1994, a Ukrainian deputy prime minister agreed with Russia that Gazprom could acquire a 51% stake in the pipeline system. In early 1995, Russia and Ukraine agreed to create a joint company, Gaztransit, to operate Ukraine's natural gas transit infrastructure in exchange for the cancellation of a substantial portion of Ukraine's debts to Russia. These agreements were never implemented, and in November 1995, the [[Verkhovna Rada of Ukraine|Verkhovna Rada]], Ukraine's parliament, adopted a law prohibiting the privatization of oil and gas assets.<ref name=pirani/>
In 1998, Gazprom and Naftohaz made a contract under which Gazprom would pay for the transit of volumes of gas, which established a link between gas prices and transit tariffs,{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} but this contract did not resolve the issue of already incurred gas debts.<ref name=pirani/> In 1998, Gazprom alleged that Ukraine had illegally diverted gas meant for export to other European countries and suspended exports of oil and electricity to Ukraine in 1999.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Gazprom also claimed that Ukraine's gas debt had reached $2.8 billion.<ref name=iea/> In 2001, Deputy Prime Minister [[Oleh Dubyna]] acknowledged that in 2000 alone {{convert|8|-|7|e9m3|abbr=off}} of Russian natural gas had been diverted from export pipelines.<ref name=pirani/> The debt issue was settled on 4 October 2001, by the signing of an intergovernmental agreement on Additional Measures Regarding the Provision of Transit of Russian Natural Gas on the Territory of Ukraine (the 2001 Transit Agreement).<ref name=iea/>
==Dispute of 2005–2006== {{Main|2005–06 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute}} {{Refimprove section|date=July 2010}} [[File:Vladimir Putin 29 December 2005-1.jpg|thumb|Then [[President of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] at a meeting on 29 December 2005, with [[Alexei Kudrin]] ([[Ministry of Finance (Russia)|Russian Finance Minister]]), [[Viktor Khristenko]] ([[Minister of Energy (Russia)|Russian Energy Minister]]), [[Alexander Medvedev]] (Deputy Chairman of the Gazprom board), [[Ivan Plachkov]] ([[Minister of Energy (Ukraine)|Ukrainian Energy Minister]]) and [[Alexey Ivchenko]] (CEO of Naftohaz), in which the dispute was discussed.]]
In 2005, negotiations over gas prices for 2006 started. Gazprom insisted on a new price of $160 per 1,000 cubic meters.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} The [[Government of Ukraine]] agreed, with the stipulation that price increases were to be gradual, in return for increased gas transit fees and changing the method of payment for transit from [[in kind|payment in kind]] to cash.<ref>Russian newspaper Kommersant daily, Tuesday, 29 March 2005</ref><!-- correct citation is needed -->{{Verify source|date=December 2008}} In May 2005, it was revealed that {{convert|7.8|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas which Gazprom had deposited in Ukrainian storage reservoirs during the previous winter had not been made available to the company.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} It remained unclear if the gas was missing, had disappeared due to technical problems, or had been stolen.<ref name=stern> {{Cite journal |title = The Russian-Ukrainian gas crisis of January 2006 |last = Stern |first = Jonathan |publisher = The Oxford Institute for Energy Studies |date = 16 January 2006 |url = http://www.oxfordenergy.org/pdfs/comment_0106.pdf |format = PDF |accessdate = 21 December 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090114195339/http://www.oxfordenergy.org/pdfs/comment_0106.pdf |archivedate = 14 January 2009 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> This issue was resolved in July 2005 by agreement between Gazprom, Naftohaz and RosUkrEnergo, according to which Naftohaz received {{convert|2.55|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas as partial settlement of the Russian gas transit over 2005 services and {{convert|5.25|e9m3|abbr=off}} was sold by Gazprom to RosUkrEnergo who has to receive it from Naftohaz.<ref name=rustocks170705> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom and Naftogaz Ukrainy settle 7.8 bcm of Russian gas in Ukrainian UGS facilities problem | publisher=RUSTOCKS.com | date =17 July 2005 | url= http://www.rustocks.com/index.phtml/pressreleases/0/46/7822?filter=2005 | accessdate =21 December 2008}} </ref> However, the negotiations between Gazprom and Naftohaz over gas prices and a new gas supply agreement failed.<ref name=iht010106> {{Cite news | title = Russia cuts off gas supply to Ukraine |work=International Herald Tribune | date =1 January 2006 | url= http://www.iht.com/articles/2006/01/01/europe/web.0101gas.php | accessdate =16 December 2008}} </ref> On 1 January 2006, Gazprom started reducing the pressure in the pipelines from Russia to Ukraine.<ref name=iht010106/>
Although Russia cut off supplies only to Ukraine, a number of European countries saw a drop in their supplies as well.<ref name=bbc020106> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine 'stealing Europe's gas' | publisher=BBC | date =2 January 2006 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4574630.stm | accessdate =16 December 2008}} </ref> The [[European Commissioner for Energy]] [[Andris Piebalgs]] and several affected member states warned that blocking of gas deliveries was unacceptable.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} [[Pascal Lamy]], director general of the [[World Trade Organization]], expressed the opinion that all [[Post-Soviet states]] should pay market prices for their energy needs in order to improve the efficiency of their economies.<ref> {{Cite news | title=Putin's Kremlin Flexes Its Muscles With Gazprom |work=Forbes | date=2 January 2006 | url=https://www.forbes.com/facesinthenews/2006/01/02/putin-gazprom-ukraine-cx_po_0102autofacescan02.html |quote=These countries should pay today's market prices for their energy to improve the efficiency of their economies |accessdate=13 January 2009 | first=Parmy | last=Olson}} </ref>
The supply was restored on 4 January 2006, after the preliminary agreement between Ukraine and Gazprom was settled.<ref name=bbc040106> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine and Russia reach gas deal | publisher=BBC | date =4 January 2006 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/4579648.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> The five-year contract was signed, although with prices set for only six months. According to the contract, the gas was sold not directly to Naftohaz, but to the intermediary Russian-Swiss company RosUkrEnergo. The price of natural gas sold by Gazprom to RosUkrEnergo rose to $230 per 1,000 cubic metres, which, after mixing it in a proportion of one-third Russian gas to two-thirds cheaper supplies from [[Central Asia]], was resold to Ukraine at a price of $95 per 1,000 cubic metres.<ref name=forbes040106>{{Cite news|title=Russia, Ukraine reach deal on gas pricing; EU relieved, oil price falls |work=Forbes |date=4 January 2006 |url=https://www.forbes.com/home/feeds/afx/2006/01/04/afx2426965.html |accessdate=17 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20081006095454/http://www.forbes.com/home/feeds/afx/2006/01/04/afx2426965.html |archivedate=6 October 2008 }} </ref><ref name=kommersant040106> {{Cite news | title = Russia, Ukraine Agree on New Gas Prices | publisher=Kommersant | date =4 January 2006 | url= http://www.kommersant.com/page.asp?id=-7864 | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> The parties also agreed to raise the tariff for transit from US$1.09 to US$1.60 per 1,000 cubic meters per 100 km; this applied not only to the transit of Russian gas to Europe, but also Turkmen gas through Russia to Ukraine.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}} On 11 January 2006, Presidents [[Vladimir Putin]] and Viktor Yushchenko confirmed that the conflict had been concluded.{{Citation needed|date=December 2008}}
One possible reason for this conflict is the more pro-[[NATO]] and European Union-style approach of the new "orange" government of Ukraine.{{Citation needed|date=July 2010}} Russia disagreed, stating they did not want to subsidize former Soviet republics.<ref name=Wpost> {{Cite news| title = Russia's State-Controlled Gas Firm Announces Plan to Double Price for Georgia |work=[[Washington Post]] | date = 3 November 2007| url= https://www.washingtonpost.com/wp-dyn/content/article/2006/11/02/AR2006110201520.html | accessdate= 3 November 2007| first=Peter| last=Finn}}</ref>
==Dispute of 2007–2008== [[File:Vladimir Putin 12 February 2008-3.jpg|thumb|Then [[President of Russia]] [[Vladimir Putin]] and [[President of Ukraine]] [[Viktor Yushchenko]] at a meeting of the Russian–Ukrainian Intergovernmental Commission at [[Moscow Kremlin|the Kremlin]] on 12 February 2008, at which the gas dispute was discussed.]]
On 2 October 2007, Gazprom threatened to cut off gas supplies to Ukraine because of unpaid debt of $1.3 billion.<ref name=bbc031007> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom may cut gas to Ukraine | publisher=BBC | date =3 October 2007 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7024294.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> This dispute appeared to be settled on 8 October 2007.<ref name=bbc081007> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine settles Russian gas row | publisher=BBC | date =8 October 2007 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7034849.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> On 5 January 2008, Gazprom warned Ukraine that it would reduce its gas supplies on 11 January if $1.5 billion in gas debts were not paid.<ref name=bbc070208> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom threatens Ukraine gas cut | publisher=BBC | date =7 February 2008 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7233401.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> Presidents Putin and Yushchenko announced on 12 February 2008, an agreement on the gas issue.<ref name=cnn120208> {{Cite news | title = Russia, Ukraine deal averts gas crisis | publisher=CNN | date =12 February 2008 | url= http://edition.cnn.com/2008/WORLD/europe/02/12/putin.russia/index.html | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> Ukraine would begin paying off its debts for natural gas consumed in November–December 2007 and the price of $179.5 would be preserved in 2008.<ref name=unian120208> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine, Russia, settle gas debt dispute | publisher=UNIAN | date =12 February 2008 | url= http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-235920.html | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref><ref name="unian120208"/> The presidents also decided to replace RosUkrEnergo and [[UkrGazEnergo]] with two new intermediaries, creating them as joint ventures of Gazprom and Naftogaz.<ref name=unian070308> {{Cite news | title = Yushchenko called Tymoshenko's policy a policy of risky ventures and intrigues | publisher=UNIAN | date =7 March 2008 | url= http://unian.net/eng/news/news-240060.html | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref>
At the end of February 2008, Gazprom threatened to reduce the supply of natural gas to Ukraine beginning on 3 March 2008, unless the pre-payment for 2008 was paid.<ref name=bbc260208> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom restarts row with Ukraine | publisher=BBC | date =26 February 2008 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7265377.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref><ref name=bbc290208> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom to reduce Ukraine's gas | publisher=BBC | date =29 February 2008 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/business/7271604.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> The [[Cabinet of Ministers of Ukraine|Ukrainian government]] said it paid for the natural gas which was consumed in 2007, but refused to pay the bill for 2008.<ref name=bbc120208a> {{Cite news | title = Russia and Ukraine reach gas deal | publisher=BBC | date =12 February 2008 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/1/hi/world/europe/7240191.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> A Gazprom spokesman claimed that the bill for {{convert|1.9|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas deliveries to Ukraine valued around $600 million remained unpaid. Ukraine disagreed as that debt accumulated in recent months when Russia used its own gas to make up for a shortfall in less expensive Central Asian gas.<ref name=france030308> {{Cite news |title = Gazprom cuts gas to Ukraine by 25% |publisher = France 24 |date = 12 February 2008 |url = http://www.france24.com/en/20080303-gazprom-cuts-gas-ukraine-25-russia-ukraine&navi=MONDE |accessdate = 17 December 2008 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090116082507/http://www.france24.com/en/20080303-gazprom-cuts-gas-ukraine-25-russia-ukraine%26navi%3DMONDE |archivedate = 16 January 2009 |df = dmy }} </ref> On 3 March, Gazprom cut its shipments to Ukraine by 25% and an additional 25% the next day, claiming that the $1.5 billion debt still was not paid, although Ukrainian officials stated it had indeed been paid.<ref name=bbc030308> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom cuts Ukraine gas supply | publisher=BBC | date =3 March 2008 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/business/7274380.stm | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> Gas supplies were restored on 5 March after Gazprom CEO [[Alexei Miller]] and Naftohaz CEO Oleh Dubyna agreed during negotiations by phone on a settlement. On 6 March, the Ukrainian cabinet refused to execute the gas agreements made by presidents Yushchenko and Putin. The Ukrainian cabinet did not want to pay in advance for 2008, and it opposed the creation of a Naftohaz–Gazprom venture that would sell gas in Ukraine.<ref name=unian060308> {{Cite news| title = Tymoshenko refused to execute gas agreements of Presidents | publisher=UNIAN| date =6 March 2008| url= http://unian.net/eng/news/news-239931.html | accessdate =17 December 2008}} </ref> Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko stated that Ukraine did not need any additional joint ventures, and as of 1 March 2008, UkrGazEnergo is no longer operating in Ukraine's domestic gas market.<ref name=Tymoshenko>{{Cite news|title=Yulia Tymoshenko is satisfied that Ukraine "withstood the confrontation" over gas |publisher=Personal web site of Yulia Tymoshenko |date=5 March 2008 |url=http://www.tymoshenko.com.ua/eng/news/first/5332/ |accessdate=17 December 2008 }}{{dead link|date=May 2016|bot=medic}}{{cbignore|bot=medic}} </ref>
==Dispute of 2008–2009== {{Main|2009 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute}}
[[File:Vladimir Putin 12 February 2008-2.jpg|thumb|Vladimir Putin and Viktor Yushchenko (12 February 2008)]]
The gas crisis of 2009 began with a failure to reach an agreement on gas prices and supplies for 2009. Ukraine owed a debt of $2.4 billion to Gazprom for gas already consumed, and Gazprom requested payment before the commencement of a new supply contract.<ref name=ukranews201108> {{Cite news |title=Gazprom, Naftogaz sign long-term cooperation deal |publisher=Ukrainian News |date=20 November 2008 |url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/164193.html |accessdate=17 December 2008 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090108160805/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/164193.html |archivedate=8 January 2009 |df=dmy }} </ref> In December 2008, despite Ukraine's repayment of more than $1 billion of its debt, Gazprom maintained its position, intending to cut the supply of natural gas to Ukraine on 1 January 2009, if Ukraine did not fully repay the remainder of $1.67 billion debt in natural gas supplies and an additional $450 million in fines levied by Gazprom.<ref name=upstream231208> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom rejects Ukraine's claim | newspaper=[[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher=NHST Media Group | date =23 December 2008 | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article168740.ece | accessdate =25 December 2008}} </ref><ref name=rian20090201> {{Cite news | title = Gazprom to receive Ukraine's $1.5 bln gas debt payment Jan. 11 | publisher=RIA Novosti | url= http://en.rian.ru/russia/20090102/119335474.html | accessdate =9 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=upstream241208> {{Cite news | title = Kiev told to pay up or gas is off | newspaper=[[Upstream (newspaper)|Upstream Online]] | publisher=NHST Media Group | date =24 December 2008 | url= http://www.upstreamonline.com/live/article168753.ece | accessdate =25 December 2008}} </ref> On 30 December, Naftohaz paid $1.522 billion,<ref name=reuters301208> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine says repaid gas debt, Russia says not yet | author=Dmitry Zhdannikov | publisher=Reuters | date =30 December 2008 | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/governmentFilingsNews/idUKLU15776220081230?sp=true | accessdate =31 December 2008}} </ref> of the outstanding debt, but the two parties were not able to agree on the price for 2009. On 17 January 2009, Russia held an international gas conference in [[Moscow]]. The EU was represented by the Presidency, the Czech Minister of Industry and Trade [[Martin Říman]], and the EU Energy Commissioner Andris Piebalgs, so that the European Union could speak with one voice.<ref name=precidency150109> {{Cite press release |title = One voice for the EU and Gas first: Member States support Czech Presidency and Commission |publisher = The Czech Presidency of the EU Council |date = 15 January 2009 |url = http://www.eu2009.cz/en/news-and-documents/news/one-voice-for-the-eu-and-gas-first:-member-states-support-czech-presidency-and-commission-6197/ |accessdate = 16 January 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20090119105109/http://www.eu2009.cz/en/news-and-documents/news/one-voice-for-the-eu-and-gas-first%3A-member-states-support-czech-presidency-and-commission-6197/ |archivedate = 19 January 2009 |df = dmy }} </ref><ref name=BBC150109B> {{Cite news | title = EU to attend gas summit in Moscow | publisher=BBC News | date =15 January 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7830517.stm | accessdate = 15 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=reuters150109> {{Cite news | title = Russian and Ukrainian PMs to hold talks on gas row | publisher=Reuters | date =15 January 2009 | url= http://uk.reuters.com/article/governmentFilingsNews/idUKLE11812920090115?sp=true | accessdate = 15 January 2009 | first=Oleg | last=Shchedrov}} </ref> Ukraine was represented by the Prime Minister Yulia Tymoshenko.<ref name=reuters170109C> {{Cite news | title = Moscow gas crisis talks go into night, no deal yet |author1=Oleg Shchedrov |author2=Simon Shuster | publisher=Reuters | date =17 January 2009 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/companyNewsAndPR/idUSLG68736920090117?sp=true | accessdate = 17 January 2009}} </ref> The conference did not achieve any solution to the crisis, and the negotiations continued bilaterally between Prime Ministers Putin and Tymoshenko. Early on 18 January 2009, after five hours of talks, Putin and Tymoshenko reached a deal to restore gas supplies to Europe and Ukraine.<ref name=reuters170109D> {{Cite news | title = Russia, Ukraine PMs agree to restore gas supplies: reports | publisher=Reuters | date =17 January 2009 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE5062Q520090117 | accessdate = 17 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=BBC180109A> {{Cite news | title = 'Gas to flow' after Moscow deal | publisher=BBC News | date =18 January 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7834796.stm | accessdate = 18 January 2009}} </ref> Both parties agreed that Ukraine would start paying European prices for its natural gas, less a 20% discount for 2009, and that Ukraine would pay the full European market price starting in 2010. In return for the discounts for 2009, Ukraine agreed to keep its transit fee for Russian gas unchanged in 2009. The two sides also agreed not to use intermediaries.<ref name=reuters180109A/><ref name=reuters180109A> {{Cite news | title = EU wary as Russia and Ukraine reach gas deal | publisher=Reuters | date =18 January 2009 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/newsOne/idUSTRE5062Q520090118?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0 | accessdate = 18 January 2009}} </ref> On 19 January 2009, [[Gazprom]] [[CEO]] Alexei Miller and the head of Naftohaz Oleh Dubyna signed an agreement on natural gas supply to Ukraine for the period of 2009–2019.<ref name=UNA190109> {{Cite news |title=Ukraine, Russia Agree On Gas Supplies To Ukraine For 2009–2019 |publisher=Ukrainian News Agency |date=19 January 2009 |url=http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/174732.html |archive-url=https://archive.is/20130105053149/http://www.ukranews.com/eng/article/174732.html |dead-url=yes |archive-date=5 January 2013 |accessdate=19 January 2009 |df=dmy }} </ref><ref name=Reuters190109A> {{Cite news | title = Russia and Ukraine sign 10-year gas supply deal |author1=Oleg Shchedrov |author2=Ron Popeski | publisher=Reuters | date =19 January 2009 | url = https://www.reuters.com/article/worldNews/idUSTRE5062Q520090119?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true | accessdate = 19 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=BBC190109> {{Cite news | title = Russia and Ukraine sign gas deal | publisher=BBC News | date =19 January 2009 | url = http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7836736.stm | accessdate = 19 January 2009}} </ref> Gas supplies restarted on 20 January 2009, and were fully restored on 21 January.<ref name=reuters210209> {{Cite news | title = Russian gas reaches Europe again | publisher=Reuters | date =21 January 2009 | url = http://uk.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUKTRE5091KI20090121?sp=true | accessdate = 24 February 2009}} </ref>
According to the EU Commission and Presidency, the Russia–Ukraine gas disputes caused irreparable and irreversible damage to customers' confidence in Russia and Ukraine, causing Russia and Ukraine to no longer be regarded as reliable partners.<ref name=BBC20090114/><ref name=reuters140109/><ref name=reuters150109/> According to reports, due to the gas crisis Gazprom lost more than $1.1 billion in revenue for the unsupplied gas.<ref name=worldpress200209/> Ukraine also incurred losses as a result of the temporary closure of its steel and chemical industries due to the lack of gas. Ukraine also lost $100 million of potential revenue in transit fees from natural gas.<ref name=worldpress200209> {{cite news | title = Russia-Ukraine 'Gas War' Damages Both Economies | url = http://www.worldpress.org/Europe/3307.cfm | author=Andrei Nesterov | publisher=Worldpress.org | date = 20 February 2009 | accessdate = 24 February 2009}} </ref>
There were also accusations of illegal diversion of natural gas by Ukraine; however, these accusations were not confirmed.<ref name=rt20090108>{{Cite news|title=Gazprom's official statement on the gas crisis |publisher=RT |date=8 January 2009 |url=http://www.russiatoday.com/news/news/35651 |accessdate=10 January 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20090118092150/http://www.russiatoday.com/news/news/35651 |archivedate=18 January 2009 }} </ref><ref name=unian210109> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine did not steal gas – Piebalgs | publisher=UNIAN | date =21 January 2009 | url= http://unian.net/eng/news/news-296245.html | accessdate =23 February 2009}} </ref> The issue of technical gas used to fuel compressor stations and to maintain gas pressure in the pipeline network remained unclear.<ref name=bbc020109> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine accused of stealing gas | publisher=BBC News | date =2 January 2009 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/7808465.stm | accessdate =2 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=kyivpost060209> {{Cite news | title = Rada commission confirms Ukraine was not stealing Russia gas | publisher=Kyiv Post | date =6 February 2009 | url= http://www.kyivpost.com/nation/35035 | accessdate =23 February 2009}} </ref> Some sources asserted that the responsibility for providing the technical gas falls to Ukraine,<ref name=rferl080109> {{Cite news | title = Russia, Ukraine Envoys In Brussels For Gas Talks With EU | publisher=RFE/RL | date =8 January 2009 | url= http://www.globalsecurity.org/military/library/news/2009/01/mil-090108-rferl01.htm | accessdate =10 January 2009}} </ref> while others say that this is the responsibility of Gazprom.<ref name=iht020109> {{Cite news | title = Russia accuses Ukraine of siphoning gas to Balkans |work=International Herald Tribune | date =2 January 2009 | url= http://www.iht.com/articles/ap/2009/01/02/europe/EU-Russia-Ukraine-Gas.php | accessdate =10 January 2009}} </ref>
There were several theories as to alleged political motives behind the gas disputes, including Russia exerting pressure on Ukrainian politicians or attempting to subvert EU and NATO expansions to include Ukraine.<ref> {{Cite news | title = Russia-Ukraine feud goes beyond gas pipes | publisher=[[The International Herald Tribune]] | date =14 January 2009 | url= http://iht.com/articles/2009/01/14/europe/gazprom.2-407519.php?page=2 | accessdate = 14 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=time070109> {{Cite news | title = Comment: Gazprom is not a market player, it’s a political weapon | author=Roger Boyes | publisher=The Times | date =7 January 2009 | url= http://www.timesonline.co.uk/tol/news/world/europe/article5458245.ece | accessdate = 8 January 2009 | location=London}}</ref><ref> {{Cite news |title = Comment: Aftermath of the Energy Crisis – Russia Still Dominant in the Market! |author = Hasan Selim Ozertem |publisher = Journal of Turkish Weekly |date = 13 February 2009 |url = http://www.turkishweekly.net/columnist/3099/aftermath-of-the-energy-crisis-russia-still-dominant-in-the-market-.html |accessdate = 13 February 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20110615004011/http://www.turkishweekly.net/columnist/3099/aftermath-of-the-energy-crisis-russia-still-dominant-in-the-market-.html |archivedate = 15 June 2011 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> Others suggested that Ukraine's actions were being orchestrated by the United States.<ref name=reuters130109/> Both sides tried to win sympathy for their arguments fighting a [[Public relations|PR]] war.<ref name=reuters712009> {{Cite news | title = What is Russia's end-game in gas row? | author=Christian Lowe | publisher=Reuters | date =7 January 2009 | url= https://www.reuters.com/article/topNews/idUSTRE5062VY20090107?pageNumber=1&virtualBrandChannel=0&sp=true | accessdate = 7 January 2009}} </ref><ref name=BBC15109A>{{Cite news | title = No clear winner in Europe's gas game | publisher=BBC News | date =15 January 2009 | url= http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/programmes/from_our_own_correspondent/7828827.stm | accessdate = 15 January 2009}} </ref>
In August 2009, it was agreed that loans worth $1.7 billion would be given to Ukraine to help it provide stable supplies of Russian gas to Europe by the [[International Monetary Fund]], the [[World Bank]], and the [[European Bank for Reconstruction and Development]], in return for reforms in Ukraine's gas sector.<ref name=BBC182009> {{cite news |date=1 August 2009 |url=http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8179461.stm |title=EU reaches gas deal with Ukraine |publisher=BBC News |accessdate=1 August 2009}} </ref>
On 28 December 2009, the [[Slovakia]]n government announced that Russia warned it would stop oil supplies to Slovakia, Hungary, and the Czech Republic over a transit price dispute with Ukraine.<ref> {{cite news |date = 28 December 2009 |url = http://www.france24.com/en/20091228-russia-warns-oil-supply-cut-off-through-ukraine-says-slovakia-petrol-europe |title = Russia warns of oil supply cut-off through Ukraine, says Slovakia |work = [[France 24]] |accessdate = 29 December 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100101074415/http://www.france24.com/en/20091228-russia-warns-oil-supply-cut-off-through-ukraine-says-slovakia-petrol-europe |archivedate = 1 January 2010 |df = dmy-all }} </ref> However, the next day, Ukraine's [[Naftohaz]] issued a statement confirming that Russia agreed to a 30% increase in the transit fees through Ukraine. The alleged rise in the tariff would be from $7.8 to $9.50 (or €6.6) per tonne of oil going through Ukraine in 2010. Additionally, unlike previous payments, new payments would be made in Euros as this was one of Ukraine's demands. Russia and Ukraine also agreed on the volume of oil to be transported through Ukraine. The overall amount of oil to be transported to Slovakia, Czech Republic, and Hungary through Ukraine in 2010 will be 15 million tonnes—a decrease from 17.1 million tonnes in 2008.<ref> {{cite news |date = 28 December 2009 |url = http://www.france24.com/en/20091229-russia-ukraine-agreement-oil-transit-naftogaz-raise-tariffs-30-percent |title = Russia agrees to higher oil transit fees with Ukraine's Naftogaz |work = [[France 24]] |accessdate = 29 December 2009 |deadurl = yes |archiveurl = https://web.archive.org/web/20100123093311/http://www.france24.com/en/20091229-russia-ukraine-agreement-oil-transit-naftogaz-raise-tariffs-30-percent |archivedate = 23 January 2010 |df = dmy-all }} </ref>
==2010 natural gas agreement== {{Main|2010 Ukrainian–Russian Naval Base for Natural Gas treaty}}
===Prologue=== After meeting her [[Prime Minister of Russia|Russian counterpart]] Putin, Ukrainian Prime Minister [[Yulia Tymoshenko|Tymoshenko]] declared on 3 September 2009, "Both sides, Russia and Ukraine, have agreed that at Christmas, there won't be [any halt in gas supplies], as usually happens when there are crises in the gas sector. Everything will be quite calm on the basis of the current agreements".<ref name="UNIAN292009"> {{cite news |date=2 September 2009 |url=http://www.unian.net/eng/news/news-334088.html |title=Putin and Tymoshenko "removed gas problems" |work=[[UNIAN]] |accessdate=2 September 2009}} </ref> Tymoshenko also said that the Ukrainian and Russian premiers had agreed that sanctions would not be imposed on Ukraine for the country buying less gas than expected and that the price of Russian gas transit across Ukraine may grow 65% till 70% in 2010.<ref name="Interfax-Ukraine392009"> {{cite news |date=3 September 2009 |url=http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/19488/ |title=Russian gas transit fee may grow 65-70% in 2010, says Ukrainian premier |work=[[Interfax-Ukraine]] |accessdate=3 September 2009 |deadurl=yes |archiveurl=https://web.archive.org/web/20120229125831/http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/19488/ |archivedate=29 February 2012 |df=dmy }} </ref> A week before Gazprom had said it expected gas transit fees via Ukraine to rise by up to 59% in 2010.<ref name="Reuters792009"> {{Cite news | title = Ukraine says has good winter gas stocks for Europe | publisher=[[Reuters]] | date =7 September 2009 | url= http://in.reuters.com/article/oilRpt/idINL762912420090907?sp=true | accessdate = 7 September 2009}} </ref>
On 8 October 2009 Tymoshenko announced that Ukrainian 2010 natural gas imports will be significantly less than in previous years "because we have less need for natural gas". Because of its [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis|economic recession]] the [[Economy of Ukraine|industries]] require far less gas. In response to Tymoshenko [[Gazprom]] Chief Executive [[Alexey Miller]] stated that Ukraine should stick to the January (2009) contract for 2010.<ref name="Kyiv Post8102009"/>
On 16 November 2009 [[Commissioner for Energy]] at the [[European Commission]] [[Andris Piebalgs]] stated that Russia and the European Union do not expect another gas conflict with Ukraine. According to him there were no gas price negotiations or questions other than that of gas payments.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/52863/ Andris Piebalgs: Russia, EU don’t expect another gas conflict with Ukraine], ''Kyiv Post'' (16 November 2009)</ref>
On 20 November 2009, the gas deal of 18 January 2009, was altered after a meeting between Tymoshenko and Putin in [[Yalta]]; meaning Ukraine would not be fined for buying less gas then the old contract stipulated, this was done in view of the [[2008–2009 Ukrainian financial crisis]].<ref>[http://news.bbc.co.uk/2/hi/europe/8369705.stm Russia agrees to ease Ukraine gas supply terms], BBC News (20 November 2009)</ref> On 24 November 2009 Gazprom and Naftohaz signed these supplements to the contract of 19 January 2009 on the purchase and sale of natural gas; according to the supplements, the annual contracted amount of gas to be supplied to Ukraine in 2010 has been set at {{convert|33.75|e9m3|abbr=off}}, instead of the {{convert|52|e9m3|abbr=off}} contracted earlier. The documents signed by the sides also stipulated that there will be no fines related to the amount of gas consumed by Naftohaz in 2009.<ref>[http://www.interfax.com.ua/eng/main/25980/ "Gazprom will cut gas supplies to Ukraine in 2010, won't fine for under-consumption in 2009"], [[Interfax-Ukraine]] (24 November 2009)</ref> Over the first ten months of 2009 Naftohaz has purchased {{convert|18.85|e9m3|abbr=off}} of gas with the contracted volume being {{convert|31.7|e9m3|abbr=off}}.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/53568/ "Naftogaz has to buy 27 bcm of gas in 2010 to avoid paying fine to Gazprom"], ''Kyiv Post'' (25 November 2009)</ref>
On 15 December 2009, Russian Energy Minister [[Sergei Shmatko]] stated he expects no problems with Ukraine over gas supplies at New Year.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/55154/ Russia energy minister sees no New Year gas war with Kyiv], ''Kyiv Post'' (15 December 2009)</ref>
===Agreement=== Ukrainian [[Prime Minister of Ukraine|Prime Minister]] [[Mykola Azarov]] and Energy Minister [[Yuriy Boyko]] were in Moscow late March 2010 to negotiate lower gas prices; neither clearly explained what Ukraine was prepared to offer in return.<ref name=Yanusell>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/business/bus_general/detail/63041/ Big plant on sale block for small price], ''Kyiv Post'' (2 April 2010)</ref> Following these talks Russian Prime Minister Vladimir Putin stated that Russia was prepared to discuss the revision of the price for [[natural gas]] it sells to Ukraine.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/62584/ Azarov: Ukraine to continue working to amend gas agreements with Russia], ''Kyiv Post'' (26 March 2009)</ref> [[File:Dmitry Medvedev in Kharkov - 21 April 2010-9.jpeg|thumb|250px|Signing of the deal reached at the [[Kharkiv]] summit on 21 April 2010 by [[Dimitry Medvedev]] and [[Viktor Yanukovych]]]] On 21 April 2010, Russian [[President of Russia|President]] [[Dmitry Medvedev]] and [[President of Ukraine|Ukrainian President]] [[Viktor Yanukovych]] signed an agreement<ref name=cnn21410>[http://www.cnn.com/2010/WORLD/europe/04/21/russia.ukraine/index.html?hpt=T2 "Russia, Ukraine agree on naval-base-for-gas deal"], CNN (21 April 2010)</ref> in which Russia agreed to a 30 percent drop in the price of [[natural gas]] sold to Ukraine. Russia agreed to this in exchange for permission to extend [[Black Sea Fleet|Russia's lease of a major naval base]] in the Ukrainian [[Black Sea]] port of [[Sevastopol]] for an additional 25 years with an additional five-year renewal option (to 2042-47).<ref name=MT21410>[http://www.themoscowtimes.com/business/article/deal-struck-on-gas-black-sea-fleet/404501.html "Deal Struck on Gas, Black Sea Fleet"], ''[[The Moscow Times]]'' (21 April 2010)</ref> As of June 2010 Ukraine pays Gazprom around $234/mcm (thousand cubic meter).<ref>[https://www.reuters.com/article/idUSLDE65H0DE20100618 UPDATE 2-Russia threatens to cut Belarus gas supplies Monday], [[Reuters]] (18 June 2010)</ref>
This agreement was subject to approval by both the [[Russian parliament|Russian]] and [[Ukrainian parliament|Ukrainian]] parliaments.<ref name=MT21410/> They did ratify the agreement on 27 April 2010.<ref name=rats/> The [[Ukrainian parliament]] ratified it after several eggs were thrown towards the [[Chairman of the Verkhovna Rada|speaker]], [[Volodymyr Lytvyn]], by deputies and other incidents.<ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/65103/ Ukrainian parliament ratifies agreement extending Russian Black Sea Fleet's presence in Crimea], ''Kyiv Post'' (27 April 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/politics/detail/65113/ "Oppositional deputies throw eggs in Lytvyn"], ''Kyiv Post'' (27 April 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/65109/ "Police clash with protesters in front of Ukrainian parliament"], ''Kyiv Post'' (27 April 2010)</ref> [[Opposition (politics)|Opposition]] members in Ukraine and Russia expressed doubts the agreement would be fulfilled by the Ukrainian side.<ref name=rats>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/65128 "Update: Ukraine, Russia ratify Black Sea naval lease"], ''Kyiv Post'' (27 April 2010)</ref><ref>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/65154/ "Agreement on Black Sea Fleet may be denounced, says Yatseniuk"], ''Kyiv Post'' (27 April 2010)</ref>
Yanukovych has defended the agreement as a tool to help stabilise the state budget.<ref name=whysign>[http://www.kyivpost.com/news/nation/detail/66624/ "Yanukovych snipes at opponent, defends fleet move"], ''Kyiv Post'' (13 May 2009)</ref> Opposition members in Ukraine described the agreement as a sell out of national interests.<ref name=whysign/>
==Dispute of 2013–2014==
===Annexation of Crimea=== {{Further|Annexation of Crimea by the Russian Federation}} In February 2014, Ukraine's [[Government-owned corporation|state-owned]] oil and gas company [[Naftogaz]] sued [[Chornomornaftogaz]] for delayed debt payments of 11.614 billion UAH (almost €1 billion) in the Economic Court of the [[Autonomous Republic of Crimea]].<ref name=unian180314>{{cite news | url = http://economics.unian.net/energetics/897959-naftogaz-trebuet-chtobyi-chernomorneftegaz-vernul-116-mlrd-griven.html | script-title=ru:"Нафтогаз" требует, чтобы "Черноморнефтегаз" вернул 11,6 млрд гривень |trans-title=Naftogaz requires that Chornomornaftogaz returned 11.6 billion UAH | agency = [[UNIAN]] | language = Russian | date = 2014-03-18 | accessdate = 2014-03-23}} </ref>
In March 2014, [[Republic of Crimea]] authorities announced that they would [[nationalization|nationalize]] the company.<ref name=interfax140314> {{cite news | url = http://www.kyivpost.com/content/ukraine/crimean-authorities-not-ruling-out-future-privatization-of-chornomornaftogaz-339347.html | title = Crimean authorities not ruling out future privatization of Chornomornaftogaz | newspaper = [[Kyiv Post]] | agency = [[Interfax-Ukraine]] | date = 2014-03-14 | accessdate = 2014-03-16}} </ref> Republic of Crimea deputy prime minister [[Rustam Temirgaliev]] said that Russia's [[Gazprom]] would be its new owner.<ref name=espreso2140314> {{cite news | url = http://espreso.tv/new/2014/03/14/naftohaz_pokynuv_svoyu_dochku___chornomornaftohaz___napryzvolyasche | script-title = uk:"Нафтогаз" покинув свою "дочку" — "Чорноморнафтогаз" — напризволяще |trans-title="Naftogaz" left his "daughter" — "Chornomornaftogas" — to fend for themselves | language = Ukrainian | work = [[Espreso TV]] | date = 2014-03-14 | accessdate = 2014-03-16 | deadurl = yes | archiveurl = https://archive.is/20140316095414/http://espreso.tv/new/2014/03/14/naftohaz_pokynuv_svoyu_dochku___chornomornaftohaz___napryzvolyasche | archivedate = 16 March 2014 | df = dmy-all }}</ref> A group of Gazprom representatives, including its head of business development, has been working at the Chornomornaftogaz head office since mid-March 2014.<ref name=interfax180314>{{cite news | url = http://en.interfax.com.ua/news/economic/196641.html | title = Crimea to hand over Chornomornaftogaz to Russia's Gazprom - deputy CEO | agency = [[Interfax-Ukraine]] | date = 2014-03-18 | accessdate = 2014-03-22}} </ref> On April 1, Russia's energy minister [[Alexander Novak]] said that Gazprom would finance an undersea gas pipeline to Crimea.<ref name=arshad/>
On 11 April 2014 the [[United States Department of the Treasury|U.S. Treasury]]'s [[Office of Foreign Assets Control]] (OFAC) announced that it had added Chornomornaftagaz to the [[Specially Designated Nationals and Blocked Persons List]] as part of the third round of U.S. sanctions.<ref name=treasury110414>{{cite press release | url = http://www.treasury.gov/press-center/press-releases/Pages/jl2355.aspx | title = Treasury Designates Seven Individuals And One Entity Contributing To The Situation In Ukraine | publisher = [[United States Department of the Treasury]] | date = 2014-04-11 | accessdate = 2014-04-12}}</ref> [[Reuters]] quoted an [[Source (journalism)#anonymous sources|anonymous]] U.S. official who explained that the United States wanted to make it impossible for Gazprom to "have dealings with Chornomorneftegaz", and if that were to happen, Gazprom itself could face sanctions.<ref name=arshad>{{cite news|last=Mohammed|first=Arshad|title=U.S. sanctions Crimea gas company, in move aimed at Gazprom|url=https://www.reuters.com/article/2014/04/11/ukraine-crisis-usa-idUSL2N0N31IN20140411|newspaper=Reuters|date=11 April 2014}}</ref>
The [[European Union]] followed suit on May 13, 2014, the first time its sanctions list has included a company (in addition to Chornomorneftegaz, a Crimean oil supplier called Feodosia was also included).<ref name=norman>{{cite news|last=Norman|first=Laurence|title=EU Modestly Expands Sanctions on Russia| url= https://online.wsj.com/news/articles/SB10001424052702303851804579557371640346660 | newspaper=[[Wall Street Journal]]|date=12 May 2014}}</ref><ref name=activ>{{cite news|title=EU punishes Russia, adds more names to sanctions list|url=http://www.euractiv.com/sections/global-europe/eu-punishes-russia-adds-more-names-sanctions-list-302078|newspaper=EurActiv|date=13 May 2014}}</ref>
===June 2014 gas supplies to Ukraine cut off=== In an attempt at [[energy security|energy independence]], Naftogaz signed a pipeline access deal with [[Slovakia]]'s [[Eustream]] on April 28, 2014. Eustream and its Ukrainian counterpart Ukrtransgaz, owned by [[Naftogaz]], agreed to allow Ukraine to use a never used (but aging, at 20 years old) pipeline on Slovakia's eastern border with [[Uzhhorod]] in [[western Ukraine]]. The deal would provide Ukraine with 3 billion cubic meters of natural gas beginning in autumn of 2014 with the aim of increasing that amount to 10 billion cubic meters in 2015.<ref name=norman/>
On 1 April 2014 [[Gazprom]] cancelled Ukraine's natural gas discount as agreed in the [[17 December 2013 Ukrainian–Russian action plan]] because its debt to the company had risen to $1.7 billion since 2013.<ref name=GWBBC16614/><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-04-01/gazprom-raises-gas-export-price-as-ukraine-looks-for-cash.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Elena | last=Mazneva | title=Gazprom Raises Gas Export Price as Ukraine Looks for Cash | date=1 April 2014}}</ref> Later that month the price “automatically” jumped to $485 per 1,000 cubic meters because the Russian government annulled an export-duty exemption for Gazprom in place since the [[2010 Kharkiv Pact]] (this agreement was denounced by Russia on 31 March 2014<ref name=ITBSTd>[http://en.itar-tass.com/russia/725964 State Duma approves denunciation of Russian-Ukrainian agreements on Black Sea Fleet], [[ITAR-TASS]] (31 March 2014)</ref>).<ref name=GWB16614/><ref>{{cite news| url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-04-03/russia-to-charge-ukraine-more-than-germany-as-gas-discounts-end.html | work=Bloomberg | first=Elena | last=Mazneva | title=Russia to Charge Ukraine More Than Germany as Gas Discounts End | date=3 April 2014}}</ref> On 16 June 2014 Gazprom stated that Ukraine's debt to the company was $4.5 billion.<ref name=GWB16614/> On 30 May 2014 Ukraine paid $786 million to Gazprom.<ref>[https://www.nytimes.com/2014/05/31/world/europe/russia-and-ukraine-in-talks-over-gas-supplies.html?_r=0 Russia and Ukraine Keep Talks Alive in Gas Feud], [[New York Times]] (MAY 30, 2014)</ref>
After intermediary (that had started in May 2014<ref name=GWB16614/>) trilateral talks between [[European Commissioner for Energy|EU Energy Commissioner]] [[Günther Oettinger]], Ukraine and Russia failed on 15 June 2014 the latter halted (after a deadline of 10 a.m. [[Moscow time]] passed without it receiving payment<ref name=GWB16614/>) its natural gas supplies to Ukraine the next day.<ref name=GWBBC16614>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27862849 Ukraine crisis: Russia halts gas supplies to Kiev], [[BBC News]] (16 June 2014)</ref> Unilaterally Gazprom decided that Ukraine had to pay upfront for its natural gas.<ref name=GWBBC16614b/> The company assured that its supplies to other European countries would continue.<ref name=GWBBC16614b>[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-27871910 Ukraine crisis: Russia halts gas supplies to Kiev], [[BBC News]] (16 June 2014)</ref> Ukraine vowed to "provide reliable supply of gas to consumers in Ukraine and we will provide reliable transit to the [[European Union]]”.<ref name=GWB16614>[https://www.bloomberg.com/news/2014-06-16/ukraine-faces-russian-gas-cutoff-as-payment-talks-fail.html Russia Cuts Gas to Ukraine While Maintaining Flow to EU ], [[Bloomberg News]] (16 June 2014)</ref> At the time about 15 percent of European Union's demand depended on Russian natural gas piped through Ukraine.<ref name=GWB16614/>
After trilateral months of talks between the European Union, Ukraine and Russia a deal was reached on 30 October 2014 in which Ukraine agreed to pay (in advance) $378 per 1,000 cubic metres to the end of 2014, and $365 in the first quarter (ending on 31 March) of 2015.<ref name=3010dEUUG/> Of its debts to Gazprom Ukraine agreed to pay of $1.45bn immediately, and $1.65bn by the end of 2014.<ref name=3010dEUUG/> It was agreed that the European Union will be acting as guarantor for Ukraine's gas purchases from Russia and would help to meet outstanding debts (using funds from existing accords with the European Union and [[IMF]]).<ref name=3010dEUUG/> The total package was worth $4.6bn.<ref name=3010dEUUG>[https://www.bbc.com/news/business-29842505 Russia-Ukraine gas deal secures EU winter supply], [[BBC News]] (31 October 2014)<br>[http://www.kyivpost.com/content/business/ukraine-secures-winter-gas-supplies-from-gazprom-370213.html Ukraine secures winter gas supplies from Gazprom], [[Kyiv Post]] (31 October 2014)</ref> According to European Union officials the deal secured that there would be no natural gas supply disruptions in other European countries.<ref name=3010dEUUG/>
==November 2015 gas supplies stop== On 25 November 2015 Gazprom halted its exports of Russian natural gas to Ukraine.<ref name="bbc251115nrgafu">[https://www.bbc.com/news/world-europe-34920207 Ukraine closes airspace to all Russian planes], [[BBC News]] (25 November 2015)</ref> According to the [[Second Yatsenyuk Government|Ukrainian government]] they had stopped buying from Gazprom because Ukraine could buy natural gas cheaper from other suppliers.<ref name="bbc251115nrgafu"/> According to Gazprom it had halted deliveries because Ukraine had not paid them for the next delivery.<ref name="bbc251115nrgafu"/> Since then, Ukraine has been able to fulfil its gas supply needs solely from European Union states. In 2018 the [[Arbitration Institute of the Stockholm Chamber of Commerce]] ordered that Ukraine's [[Naftogaz]] should import 5 billion cubic meters of gas annually from Russia, as required under its 2009 contract with Russia’s [[Gazprom]].<ref name=bl-20180110>{{cite news |url=https://www.bloomberg.com/news/articles/2018-01-10/russian-gas-return-to-ukraine-to-cost-eu-traders-1-billion |title=Russian Gas Return to Ukraine to Cost EU Traders $1 Billion |last=Mazneva |first=Elena |publisher=Bloomberg |date=10 January 2018 |accessdate=15 August 2018}}</ref>
==Public reaction in Ukraine== {{Main|Remember about the Gas – Do not buy Russian goods!}} {{See also|Do not buy Russian goods!}} Political pressure from Russia to Ukraine led to the emergence of a public campaign to boycott Russian goods in Ukraine during the [[2005–06 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute|gas conflict of 2005–2006]]. Active actions in the campaign also continued in early 2009—during the [[2009 Russia–Ukraine gas dispute|gas war of 2008–2009]].

{{Infobox prepared food | name = Spring soup | image = Spring_veggie_soup.jpg | image_size = 250px | caption = Spring vegetable soup | alternate_name = | country = | region = | creator = | course = | type = [[Soup]] | served = | main_ingredient = [[Asparagus]] or other spring [[vegetable]]s; [[broth]], [[chowder]], or [[Bisque (food)|bisque]] | variations = | calories = | other = }} [[File:Spring_pea_soup_with_cr%C3%A8me_fra%C3%AEche_and_bread.jpg#file|thumb|right|200px|Spring pea soup]]
'''Spring soup''' is a [[soup]] made with ingredients that are only in season for a short period during spring.<ref>Dipping, Caroline. (April 30, 2008) ''[[The San Diego Union-Tribune]]'' [http://www.signonsandiego.com/uniontrib/20080430/news_1f30readers.html "Spring soup has a limited season."] Section: Lifestyle; Page E2.</ref> Although [[asparagus]] largely characterizes spring soup,<ref name="bowl">Burckhardt, Ann. (April 3, 1988) [[Star Tribune]] ''Springtime soups that'll bowl you over.'' Section: Taste; Page 15E.</ref> spring soup may include just about any spring vegetable added to a [[broth]], [[chowder]], or [[Bisque (food)|bisque]].<ref>Parsons, Russ. (February 27, 2008) [[Los Angeles Times]] ''[http://www.latimes.com/features/food/la-fo-calcook27feb27,1,7713837.story The California cook: Ready to get fresh? A spring soup flirtation.]'' Section: Food; Page 1.</ref> Spring soup is popular largely because it includes fresh ingredients not seen for a while by the consumer.<ref>Snedaker, Kit. (May 23, 1994) [[New Jersey Record]] ''A bowl of spring's freshness.'' Page B3.</ref>
==Characteristics== Where winter soups are hearty to "warm and fortify", spring soups aim to celebrate "new skies and freshness" by being "delicate and light, pretty and promising."<ref>Winnecke, Joycelyn. (April 17, 1999) [[Scripps Treasure Coast Newspapers|Vero Beach Press Journal]] ''Spring Soups: Bright, light, tested for taste.'' Section: Lifestyle; Page C4.</ref> Spring soups need lighter, brighter tastes and textures than their winter counterparts.<ref>Kapoor, Sybil. (May 13, 2007) [[The Sunday Times]] ''Liquid lunch;Cooking;Food & Drink.'' Section: Features; Page 48.</ref> A reason for this is that spring soups "capture the essence of the season in a clean-tasting, refreshing broth that showcases the pure flavors" of its ingredients.<ref>Bianco, Marie. (April 22, 1987) [[Newsday]] ''[https://news.google.com/archivesearch?hl=en&um=1&ie=UTF-8&tab=wn&q=A+spring+soup+needs+to+capture+the+essence+of+the+season+in+a+clean-tasting,+refreshing+broth+that+showcases+the+pure+flavors+of+these+ingredients Put some spring in your soup.]'' Section: Food; Page 3.</ref>
Ingredients used in spring soup include a [[purée]] of [[pea]], [[asparagus]], [[rapini]], and [[fennel]],<ref>Kates, Joanne. (June 2, 2007) [[The Globe and Mail]] ''Karuchie a real gamble.'' Section: Globe Style; Page L10.</ref> with asparagus being considered the quintessential spring vegetable to largely characterize spring soup.<ref name="bowl"/> Spring soups typically show a subtle green color to reflect spring.<ref>Scattergood, Amy. (March 15, 2006) [[Los Angeles Times]] ''[https://pqasb.pqarchiver.com/latimes/access/1003264491.html?dids=1003264491:1003264491&FMT=ABS&FMTS=ABS:FT&date=Mar+15%2C+2006&author=Amy+Scattergood&pub=Los+Angeles+Times&desc=Simplicity%3A+let+it+rule%3B+Insanely+good+dishes+that+are+a+snap+to+make%3F+We+kid+you+not.&pqatl=google Simplicity: let it rule; Insanely good dishes that are a snap to make? We kid you not.]'' Section: Food; Page F1.</ref>
==History== In 1828, ''[[The British Almanac]]'' provided [[Household management|housekeepers]]' information to add spring soup to a July menu.<ref>''[[The British Almanac]]'': By The Society for the Diffusion of Useful Knowledge (Great Britain). (1828) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=UXQ3AAAAMAAJ&q=spring+soup+date:1821-1830&dq=spring+soup+date:1821-1830&lr=&num=100&as_brr=0&pgis=1 Housekeepers' Information]''</ref> In 1896, the [[Holland Society of New York]] published a spring soup recipe that included [[amontillado]], [[olives]], [[almonds]], [[chicken]], and [[radishes]].<ref>[[Holland Society of New York]] (1765) ''[https://books.google.com/books?lr=&num=100&as_brr=0&q=Spring+Soup.+AMONTILLADO.+Olives.+Almonds.+Radishes+Chicken+Halibut&btnG=Search+Books Year Book of the Holland Society of New-York By Holland Society of New York Vol. for 1886/87.]'' Original from the University of Virginia. Digitized Aug 21, 2007. (Includes the Annual dinner of the Holland Society of New-York)</ref> In 1898, spring soup was defined as a soup having a stock with any spring vegetables added that have first been [[parboiled]] in water, with the soup often colored with [[caramel]].<ref>[[Mary Foote Henderson|Henderson, Mary Foote]]. (1898) ''[https://books.google.com/books?id=vnAEAAAAYAAJ&pg=PA85&dq=spring+soup#PPA85,M1 Practical Cooking and Dinner Giving: A Treatise Containing Practical Instructions in Cooking.]'' Publishers: Harper & brothers.</ref>

{{Refimprove|date=December 2015}} <!-- what is missing? {{incomplete|date=December 2015}} }} -->'''Subnivean climate''' (From [[Latin language|Latin]] for "under" (''[[wikt:sub|sub]]-'') and "of snow" (''[[wikt:niveus|niveus]]'') and English -an<ref> https://www.merriam-webster.com/dictionary/subnivean </ref>. This is the environment of many [[winter|hibernal]] animals, as it provides insulation and protection from predators. The subnivean climate is formed by three different types of snow metamorphosis: destructive metamorphosis, which begins when snow falls; constructive metamorphosis, the movement of [[water vapor]] to the surface of the snowpack; and melt metamorphosis, the [[melting]]/[[Sublimation (phase transition)|sublimation]] of snow to water vapor and its refreezing in the snowpack. These three types of metamorphosis transform individual [[snowflake|snowflakes]] into ice crystals and create spaces under the snow where small animals can move.
== Subnivean fauna== Subnivean [[fauna]] includes small mammals such as [[mouse|mice]], [[vole]]s, [[shrew]]s, and [[lemming]]s that must rely on winter snow cover for survival. These mammals move under the snow for protection from heat loss and some predators. In winter regions that do not have [[permafrost]], the subnivean zone maintains a temperature of close to 32°F (0°C) regardless of the temperature above the snow cover, once the snow cover has reached a depth of six inches (15 cm) or more. The sinuous tunnels left by these small mammals can be seen from above when the snow melts to the final inch or so.
Some winter predators, such as [[fox]]es and large [[owl]]s, can hear their prey through the snow and pounce from above. [[Ermine]] (stoats) can enter and hunt below the snowpack. [[Snowmobile]]s and [[All-terrain vehicle|ATV]]s can collapse the subnivean space. Skis and snow shoes are less likely to collapse subnivean space if the snowpack is deep enough.
Larger animals also use subnivean space. In the Arctic, [[ringed seal]]s have closed spaces under the snow and above openings in the ice. In addition to resting and sleeping there, the female seals give birth to their pups on the ice. Female [[polar bear]]s also den in snow caves to give birth to their young. Both types of dens are protected from exterior temperatures. Formation of these large spaces is from the animals' activity, not ground heat.
==Subnivean climate formation== === Deconstructive metamorphosis === Deconstructive metamorphosis begins as the snow makes its way to the ground, often melting, refreezing, and settling. Water molecules become reordered, causing the snowflakes to become more spherical in appearance.<ref name=halfpenny>{{Cite book | last1 = Halfpenny | first1 = James | last2 =Ozanne | first2 = Roy | title = Winter: An Ecological Handbook | publisher = Johnson Publishing Company | year =1989}}</ref> These melting snowflakes fuse with others around them, becoming larger until all are uniform in size. While the snow is on the ground, the melting and joining of snow flakes reduces the height of snowpack by shrinking air spaces, causing the density and mechanical strength of the snowpack to increase. Freshly fallen snow with a [[density]] of 0.1 g/cm<sup>3</sup> has very good insulating properties; however as time goes on, due to destructive metamorphism, the insulating property of the snowpack decreases, because the air spaces between snowflakes disappear. Snow that has been on the ground for a long period of time has an average density of 0.40 g/cm<sup>3</sup> and conducts heat well; however, once a base of 50 cm of snow with a density around 0.3 g/cm<sup>3</sup> has accumulated, temperatures under the snow remain relatively constant because the greater depth of snow compensates for its density. Destructive metamorphosis is a function of time, location, and weather. It occurs at a faster rate with higher temperatures, in the presence of water, under larger temperature gradients (e.g., warm days followed by cold nights), at lower elevations, and on slopes that receive large amounts of [[solar radiation]]. As time goes on, snow settles, compacting air spaces, a process expedited by the packing force of the wind.<ref name="marchand">{{Cite book | first = Peter | last = Marchand | title = Life in the Cold | place= Hanover | publisher = University Press of New England | year = 1996 |ISBN = 978-0874517859 }}</ref>
Compaction of snow reduces the penetration of long- and short-wave radiation by reflecting more radiation off the snow. This limitation of light transmission through the snowpack decreases light availability under the snow. Only 3% of light can penetrate to a depth of 20 cm of snow when the density is 0.21 g/cm<sup>3</sup>. At a depth of 40 cm, less than 0.2% of light is transmitted from the snow surface to ground below. This decrease in light transmission occurs up to the point at which critical compaction is reached. This occurs because the surface area of the ice crystal decreases and it causes less refraction and scattering of light. Once densities reach 0.5 g/cm<sup>3</sup>, total surface area is reduced, which in turn reduces internal refraction and allows light to penetrate deeper into the snowpack.<ref name="marchand"/>
=== Constructive metamorphosis === Constructive metamorphosis is caused by the upward movement of water vapor within the snowpack. Warmer temperatures are found closer to the ground because it receives heat from the core of the earth. Snow has a low [[thermal conductivity]], so this heat is retained, creating a temperature gradient between the air underneath the snowpack and the air above it. Warmer air holds more water vapor. Through the process of sublimation, the newly formed water vapor travels vertically by way of diffusion from a higher concentration (next to the ground) to a lower concentration (near the snowpack surface) by traveling through the air spaces between ice crystals.<ref name=hindelang>{{Cite web | last = Hindelang | first = Mary | title = The Science of Winter Ecology | url=http://www.ed.mtu.edu/esmis/winter/ecology.html}}</ref> When the water vapor reaches the top of the snowpack, it is subjected to much colder air, causing it to condense and refreeze, forming ice crystals at the top of the snowpack that can be seen as the layer of crust on top of the snow.
===Melt metamorphism=== Melt metamorphism is the deterioration of snow by melting. Melting can be stimulated by warmer [[ambient temperature]]s, rain, and fog. As snow melts, water is formed and the force of gravity pulls these molecules downward. En route to the ground, they refreeze, thickening in the middle stratum. During this refreezing process, energy is released in the form of latent heat. As more water comes down from the surface, it creates more heat and brings the entire snowpack column to near equal temperature. The [[firn|firnification]] of the snow strengthens the snowpack, due to the bonding of grains of snow. Snow around trees and under canopies melts faster due to the reradiation of long-wave radiation. As snow gets older, particles of impurities (pine needles, soil, and leaves, for example) accrue within the snow. These darkened objects absorb more short-wave radiation, causing them to rise in temperature, also reflecting more long-wave radiation.
